Subjective: Headaches x 2 months, worsening. Right-sided, sometimes diffuse. Mild nausea at worst, no vomiting. Glare in vision, no flashes of light. Interferes with activities (e.g., volleyball). Family hx migraines (father), cluster headaches (grandfather). No known serious family hx (tumors). No recent stress. No coffee/energy drinks. Tried paracetamol, ibuprofen effective. Headaches occur ~weekly, last few days. Prefers dark, quiet room. Alcohol occasionally, no smoking, no drugs. Student (medicine, 2nd year). Request: Dx clarification (migraine vs. cluster), best course of action.
Objective: BP 120/80, HR 50. Neuro exam: Cranial nerves intact, fingertip-nose normal, arm/leg strength good, Romberg normal. Gait slightly unsteady but manageable.
Assessment: Migraine, likely. Fits with symptoms (headache, glare, photophobia/phonophobia), family history, and neurological exam. Less likely cluster headache given duration and presentation. No red flags for secondary headache.
Plan: 1. Read information on thuisarts.nl regarding migraine. 2. Start analgesia (paracetamol 4x2 tabs or ibuprofen) at onset of symptoms. 3. Keep headache diary (print provided) to track frequency, duration, triggers, and severity. 4. Follow-up in 4 weeks with diary for review. 5. Return sooner if symptoms worsen significantly or change.
